newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Unilever doesn't plan big selloff - Tabaksblat.
newsitem.headline: Unilever doesn't plan big selloff - Tabaksblat.

text.p: Unilever's drive to increase profitability will not result in the sale of 20 percent of its businesses, as some analysts have speculated, co-chairman Morris Tabaksblat said in a newspaper interview.
Tabaksblat said Unilever NV /Plc was currently reviewing the performance of businesses which accounted for some 20 percent of its annual turnover of around 80 billion guilders.
"Our first goal is improving profitability. If that doesn't succeed we can divest, but it would certainly be less than half of that 20 percent." he said.
Tabaksblat said Unilever aimed to complete the current review in two years but said other businesses might well have to be reviewed in the future. "It's an ongoing process," he said.
Tabaksblat said Unilever had been refocusing on its core businesses since the mid-1980s, in some cases selling off whole divisions, such as animal feed and packaging.
"Within our core businesses, however, we haven't looked closely enough at what is really core, where we really create added value," he said.
Tabaksblat said that in addition to streamlining its existing businesses in Europe and North America, Unilever would continue to expand in emerging markets.
These would generate some 35 percent of total turnover in the year 2000 and 50 percent by 2010, he said.
Tabaksblat said there were no differences of opinion between himself and his fellow co-chairman Niall FitzGerald.
FitzGerald told Reuters Financial Television earlier this month that the Anglo-Dutch consumer products giant needed to sharpen its focus.
"We will judge how we change (the portfolio) based on the ability of individual parts of the portfolio to add real value, economic value, which translates into shareholder value."
